reviewText:
Before we begin the review, the most common reason I see people brush off this game is because of it's title. To clear up the confusion, the title is NOT referring to the butt floss type of underwear. It is referring to the musical instrument of the violin in reference to classical musician J.S. Bach.

G-Senjou No Maou Review
(Score Breakdown Found at the Bottom of Review)

Introduction & My Personal History With This Game:
If I recall correctly, my first experience with G-senjou no Maou was in 2011. I'll confess, I was a bad person and pirated the game, along with the fan translation patch, because I didn't have a legal way of purchasing this game at the time. I always feel terrible any time I do this for a product, especially if I turn out really liking the product. However, as with every product that I've ever acquired in this manner, I promised to myself that, if this game was ever officially localized, I would be sure to make it an immediate purchase. With that out of the way let's jump right into the review.

Differences Between The Fan Translation and Official Localization:
First off, the interface is much cleaner. I don't remember every aspect of the original interface, but everything just feels smoother". Switching between the currently open scene
recommended: and save/load screen is very quick and doesn't seem jarring at all.\nThe next biggest thing to talk about is the removal of the sex scenes (H-Scenes). Personally
hoursPlayed: I prefer these scenes being removed. If you are someone who enjoys the H-scenes when playing Visual Novels (VN's)
voteText: then I'm sorry to report that they are not present in this current version.\nthe artwork appears to have had some work done on it's sprites to make them look quite a bit better
helpfulPercent: and the new 720p resolution is awesome.\nLastly
votesHelpful: from the 6 hours I've put into this game so far
votesTotal: I can safely say that I prefer this translation to the original fan translation. Sentences just seem to be structured a little bit better
votesFunny:
and It just feels easier to read.

Story:
This visual novel is a mystery story at it's core
commentsCount: and places the themes of money and corruption front and center. The story of G-senjou no Maou centers around our main protagonist Azai Kyousuke; a high school student who is a prodigy when it comes to making money. Being the adopted son of the big shot Yakuza (gangster) family known as the Azai
column16: we follow him as he tries to live his double life of normal high school and the dark and twisted world of the Yakuza. When a new transfer student named Usami joins his class at school
column17: and other characters start to slowly learn of his double life
column18: Kyousuke will find himself in over his head well before he knows what hit him. While all this is going on
column19: we learn of a certain character named "Maou" who is lurking in the shadows planning something huge
column20: that will shake the very foundation of the city. Unfortunately
column21: I cannot give further specific details on the story without delving into spoilers.\nThe pacing is the story's high point. It knows just how much time to spend with each expositional scene
column23:
and event. The level of immersion is also phenomenal. You'll find yourself absorbed into this story from beginning to end.

Characters:
The highlight of this VN is it's unique cast of characters. Azai Kyousuke (our protagonist
column24: and player character) is as morally grey as they come without being a strict anti-hero. Learning more about his skills
column25: and seeing how he deals with each situation is one of the biggest reasons to keep reading hour after hour.\nAizawa Eiichi (the "best bud" character) isn't anything like what you're used to seeing in most VN's. He's a slimeball through and through. While often pretending to be cute
column28: his true nature is that of a very angry little man who wants to go out with (and "bow chicka wow wow") a MUCH older woman.\nEach of the girls are also very well developed
column29: especially the main girl Usami.\nUsami Haru is very good at noticing when people are lying
column30: and is incredibly socially awkward. She loves using game metaphors (especially those referencing the RPG genre).\nShiratori Mizuha knows about what Kyousuke is up to after school when he returns home. She's a constant threat to our protagonist. If she was to say something he could easily lose his comfortable  life.\nMiwa Tsubaki is perhaps the most generic of the girls. She is the class representative of Kyousuke's class
column31: and writes down absolutely ANYTHING that happens during a day in her diary.\nAzai Kanon is the last of the girls that Kyousuke interacts with on a daily basis. She is the adoptive sister of our protagonist
column32: so they are not related by blood. She is an incredibly talented figure skater
column33: who is trying to making it into the olympics. She adores her adopted brother and will often go out of her way to see him as much as she can.\nThe antagonists are also very good
column34: but even mentioning their names (let alone their personalities) would be a huge spoiler. That said
column35: just keep in mind that when they do show up
column36: that they're going to be the highlight of the scene currently taking place.\n\nArtwork
column39: and Effects:\nThere isn't really much to really say here. As far as all the visual effects go
column40: they're all top notch and show just how high the production values for this VN are. The new 720p resolution is also VERY welcome.\n\nSound
column42: and Voice Acting:\nAgain there isn't much to say about the Sound effects. They are simply crisp
column44: and appropriate.\nThe music leans heavily towards the classical genre of music
column45: and remixes of said classical music. This is appropriate as Kyousuke is a huge fan of classical music
column46: especially J.S. Bach. There are some custom tracks
column47: but they are far fewer in number than the classical songs on the soundtrack. Almost all tracks feature some kind of violin.\n\nThe voice acting in this game is top notch. All characters are voiced

Conclusion:
Back in January of 2012 I listed G-senjou no Maou as my favorite VN at the time. Although that list has changed a lot after reading the Zero Escape series and Danganronpa series

reviewText:
G-senjou no Maou – The devil on G-String is a mystery-thriller visual novel is developed by AKABEiSoft2 and published by Sekai Project and was released on November 5, 2015 on the Steam platform. Originally released in 2008, the Steam Release of G-senjou no Maou – The Devil on G-String marks AKABEisoft2’s first officially localized release. The Devil on G-String prices at $19.99 for the standard edition of the game, and $39.99 for a fully-voiced (in Japanese) version of the game. Both versions of the game will be discounted 30% until November 12.

The Story You will play as Azai Kyousuke, the adoptive son of a yakuza boss you will see the world through his eyes as he puts up a facade of being a “rich person with taste” to keep his classmates away from him. He often enjoys listening to Bach and “working” part time for his stepfather. But when a beautiful girl named Usami Haru appears in town along with an international criminal known as “Maou,” they bring with them their cat-and-mouse game of plotting and intrigue.

Visual and Music elements Visual Elements
Backgrounds and CGs are beautiful and detailed very well done overall very smooth looking sprites and they look really cute when i first saw Miwa Tsubaki sprite with the cute “Ahoge” above her head my first impression was “wow she looks really cute”. There is also time based character color calibration which is a really cool addition because it makes the character have Evening and Night color immersion which adds to the overall atmosphere of the visual novel.

Music in the menu give that creepy feeling when you play in the dark I loved the overall creepy atmosphere it manages to set and I loved the way they can turn the creepy and dark atmosphere into a cheery and cute atmosphere all with the use of music that goes along with the gloomy and bright colors being put to use. Overall music being used in the game is good

Interface and FeaturesThey have features like having song titles appearing at at the top right of the screen when a new song plays with the composer name.
They also have the feature to change specific characters text colors which not many Visual Novel have this feature which I find this a nice feature to have because sometimes the words colors may blend into the background and thus making it very hard to read them.

To sum up I would definitely recommend this visual novel to anyone because this visual novel overall would appeal to most people and would recommend anyone that likes mystery/thriller genre with investigations going on all around in the visual novel.

Click here for the full review![azusantiara.wordpress.com]

reviewText:
TLDR: Fantastic cat-and-mouse detective story presented as a visual novel.

At first glance I thought this was just another dating simulator, but all the Steam reviews said it wasn't. And I'm glad I was curious enough to buy it. It's actually a really good detective visual novel. The story is akin to Death Note's - a genius detective tries to stop an evil criminal, and they engage in a cat-and-mouse game of outdoing each other.  At the time of this writing I'm near the end of Chapter 4 and found myself blown away by a plot twist I totally didn't see coming.

A word of warning though - this is not traditional game. It's a visual novel and while there is the occasional choice you have to make, it's 99% reading. The story is broken in chapters, and each one will take a couple of hours or more to read through. Along the way you meet interesting characters, and each chapter of the novel usually focuses on a crime that affects one of them.

Luckily the reading is made bearable thanks to the pretty anime art that accompanies each character. I recommend buying the fully-voiced edition as it breathes more life to each character. The music that accompanies the game is made up of remixed classical music from Bach, Beethoven, etc and gives the game a unique touch.

Are there any flaws? Not really - just that sometimes the story digresses into parts that seem pointless. But sometimes these seemingly meaningless diversions turn out to play an important part later. ;)

A picture of a few girls for the protagonist to pursue is as far from the focus of this story as it gets, but that's what sells the copies in the marketspace. The name itself is a reference to Air on G-string"

Story:

recommended: particularly if you're the sort who enjoys crime mysteries where the villain and protagonist clash in deadly knife fights of razor sharp wit. The girls who you are given the option of pursuing are a distraction in the most literal sense

some of which do an amazing job of setting the mood. A remix of "Marche Slave" was used as a mood piece and character theme for a mafia boss and I couldn't get enough of it.

Fin:
There's not much more to say than that. This isn't The Fruit of Grisaea. Grisaea was entertaining and had its dark moments

reviewText:
Warning: Terrible formatting ahead
This is one of my favorite visual novels. Top 5 for sure.
A lot of visual novels start off slow, making you used to the characters before you get to choose which one you want to know more about further. This can make early reading a chore for people who just want to read a story and find it difficult to make an emotional connection with each character through hours of comedy.

This novel is not like that at all. This novel starts off strong, and makes you come back because you want to know more. It grabs your curiousity, and pulls you in. This is the first and only novel I've read that does this. Not once did I feel like I had to struggle through content I didn't care about in order to get to the main dish. It's full tension from start to finish.

Unlike some visual novels, this one is very linearly story-oriented. However, there are plenty of choices to be made here.
There are route branches to different heroines, but doing so will abandon the main story, or canon route if you want to call it that, and grant you a character-specific route. While I'm not personally into that, more power to the people who are. That's a good thing, right?

Story:
The story gives me a slight Death Note vibe due to the cat and mouse battle between wits, while still being original and not copying. This is, in my opinion, a must read for people who are into that genre, and I would recommend it to anyone who likes Death Note or anything mystery/crime.
There are a lot of dark themes, and it's definitely not a fanfare title for sure. If you prefer titles like Sakura <insert whatever here> or NekoPara, this is probably not for you. May contain badassery.

Artwork:
The artwork is fairly decent, better than average to most standards. Steam's release had a lot of UI improvements made, which I only welcome. There is plenty of CG to be unlocked, and it looks pretty.
Compared to Akabei Soft2's previous releases, it's definitely an improvement.

Soundtrack:
Befitting to the title of the novel, the soundtrack consists of remixes of classical music. Need I say more? There's a wide variety of classical composers, ranging from Beethoven to Bach to Tchaikovsky and the list goes on. As a Norwegian, it makes me feel special that there's even Edvard Grieg in here. Hot daym.
And yes, the title theme is Air on G-String. No more G-string jokes pls.

A few last words:
A complaint I see is the price difference between the voiced and the unvoiced version, but this is because of how Japanese voice licensing works. It's expensive, and you're given a choice, rather than being forced to pay full price. How some people see this as a negative thing confuses me.

reviewText:
G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String Review
Personal History
I’ve been a fan of visual novels for quite a time now. It probably stemmed from my love for immersive stories and because of that, I was constantly reading as a child. Since I was kid, I was into anime and always heard of these “visual novels” but never really understood what exactly it was until I got around to reading them. I remember reading the fan translated G-senjou quite a while back and it left quite an impact on me and would lead to my eventual obsession into all things visual novel related. (I have no qualms towards pirating only because it was next to impossible to read English translated visual novels back then. But since that’s a bad excuse, I generally go out of my way to buy visual novels I’ve read before as they come onto steam to make up for pirating and also to support the work that went into making the product.)

Story
“The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes.” –Sherlock Holmes from The Hound of the Baskerville

For this visual novel in particular, the story is heavily driven by corruption, money, and revenge. While it does have its light-hearted moments, this novel, at its core, is of the mystery - and thriller - genre and shows this through many different scenarios similar to that of Sherlock Holmes and Moriarty. The story itself begins a bit slow, but as more and more mysteries start revealing others and the main villain, “Maou”, shows up in the shadows, the story accelerates and it becomes very captivating. It was next to impossible - for me - to peel my eyes away from the computer screen; especially at moments like the previously mentioned “Sherlock Holmes and Moriarty”-esque scenes between the main characters Kyousuke, Haru -and others - and the villain Maou.

Sound/Music and Voice Acting
Let me go ahead and say I’m a big fan of classical music. I’m also a big fan of Japanese pop music. (My computer and phone are filled with anime openings and endings that I listen to constantly). You can expect a lot of high paced violin and orchestral related music. Me trying to be as objective as possible, I really did think that all the music was very well done. It fit the mood of each scene and served to bring out the best in G-senjou.

The voice acting is truly a wonderful addition. There really isn’t much else I can say about that. They really do bring out the best. Sometimes I had goosebumps at just how much of an immersive experience it was. Every single character that was voiced was spot on and made for an exponentially better read. That being said, the voice acting is an add-on for the Steam version. Personally I kind of want to punch you – or maybe drop-kick you - if you don’t buy it with voices, but I do understand that some people can’t pass up a cheaper product.

Artwork
In my opinion, I always thought the artwork was pretty good. It isn’t super godly tier artwork, but it’s very beautifully done. The characters are properly portrayed, the sprites are cute as heck, and transition and effects are very well done. I do enjoy the high resolution as compared to the fan translation though. I noticed people complaining about how the event CGs was cut due to the new aspect ratio, but I honestly didn’t even notice on my run through of the game even though I played the original version. Everything still looks amazing.

Cut Scenes
Yes, a couple of H-scenes are cut. Coming from someone who's read it WITH the H-scenes, it didn't really...mess with the immersive-ness of the experience.

Personal Enjoyment
Obviously this is the only category that truly matters. Reading this way back when – I forget the actual year because I’m a forgetful person – this transformed my visual novel experience. It made me realize how amazing a well written story could be for a visual novel setting with its artwork and voice acting. To this day, it has remained a contender for my favorite visual novel of all time and that will probably remain a fact for many decades to come.

I’m not going to numerically break down the scores for the key points of this visual novel but I will rate my personal enjoyment. 10/10, totally, 100% best visual novel ever, will read again. But in all honesty, this is truly a work of art. Perhaps even a masterpiece, at least in my subjective view. But in the end, only you can decide whether or not you want to read said visual novel.

“There is nothing like first-hand evidence.” –Sherlock Holmes from A Study in Scarlet

-Dris

reviewText:
G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String is a brooding Visual Novel about a young man who is both a high school student and an officer in the Yakuza (Japanese mafia). It's a shame this is partly set in a high school because the rest of the story is a wonderfully dark drama of a young man who is in forced bondage to the mafia.

This story reminds me of Death Note (a good thing) because of the clever battle of wits and the divided loyalties - except that Death Note is better and more polished. Be aware you may despise some of the characters for what they do, so you may feel repulsed by the game when forced to go through the story with them. Me, well, I found the dilemmas too interesting.

G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String is a worthy purchase when it's on sale. Note: there is no screenshot tool and apparently the sexual content has been removed.

reviewText:
Honestly probably one of the best visual novels I've ever played. Recommend that you play through the  true route first and then maybe go back and do the side routes. The True route is more of a continuous story whereas the side routes sorta derail the whole thing and make the conflicts that were going on throughout the story suddenly disappear.

A full full recommend for anyone who's in for a good read. Do NOT let anyone tell you this is 'just an eroge' or 'a dating-sim' either. It's not. In the same way a sex scene doesn't make a movie a porno--a hentai scene doesn't make a visual novel an eroge. Though apparently this is the All-Ages version so the H-scenes were taken out--which I'm actually all for so that's cool.

Also--incredible VA work so I recommend the voiced version.

reviewText: This VN is a masterpiece. It has a great story, excellent art, interesting characters, a great soundtrack, and multiple endings. It will keep you entertained for a very long time. I just finished one ending and it's taken over 20 hours already (and that was probably one of the shortest!). That being said, I can't wait to finish the other 6! It's definitely worth picking up, if you're still on edge about getting it.\n\nAs for the voiced version, it's up to you whether or not to get it, but I'd definitely recommend it. I basically went broke after buying it, but I don't regret my decision in the slightest. The voice acting was fantastic. A lot of people are against it because they think it's a ripoff, but understand the licensing issues. It costs extra for them to get the voices in the game, and it's your choice whether to get the voices or not. Some other VNs are quite expensive just because they're voiced, so at least you have option to get it cheaper non-voiced here, if you don't mind that. Price-wise as well, the voiced version here matches the same as some other high-quality fully-voiced VNs here on Steam, if not cheaper than others.

reviewText:
A fantastic visual novel, and the money was well spent (bought alongside the Japanese voice pack). Please do not let the title of the novel mislead you. Especially those of you from the western world. It is a story of loyalty, revenge, unforgivable crimes and deep-seeded hatred. A brilliantly written piece of work, aimed at those who enjoy reading crime mysteries where the protagonist and antagonist clash time and time again. The dialogue between protagonist and antagonist is also pretty spectacular. An emotional rollercoaster. Arguably the best visual novel ever made.

Hope all of you out there who enjoy crime mysteries decide to pick this up. It's a definite steal for the price they're providing it at here on Steam.

8.5/10

reviewText: This visual novel was one of the first anime-related pieces of fiction I'd ever experienced and remains dear to my heart. The true route in this story will completely blow your mind. I absolutely cannot recommend this enough.\n\nP.S. Usami Haru is a top-tier anime girl.

reviewText:
Yessssssss! I played this game 2 years ago and I completly fell in love with it! I saw that this was on Steam just now and I immediatly bought it. It was mostly because of this game that I got into visual novels.

GameplayFrom what I have read, the H-scenes have been taken out, but those aren't really worth caring about. This gem of a game has an amazing story and there are many hilarious parts (especially with your green-haired best friend). The gameplay is zilch however, so be warned. This IS a visual novel after all. Pretty much all of the music reflects the protag's choice in music, so it's really immersive (he likes Classical so most of the original sound track is Classical music). The main route is Haru's story and is definetly the true route while the other endings are for the other heroines. There are some bads ends though if you choose a choice incorrectly.

Personal ReviewI'm really glad that Steam is finally getting some awesome VNs! I would give this a 9.5/10 and not feel sorry. No offense to those of y'all out there, but Nekopara and games like that have ****ing terrible stories. Please give this game a chance! Not sure if this game will be this much on sale afterwards, so take this as what you will. Keep it up Steam!
I'd like to see Fate/Stay Night and Tsukihime up next!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Well, after 16 hours I finally finished what was described to me as a masterpiece". While it is definitely a good read
date: it had a few glaring flaws that need to be addressed.\n\n1) Unlikable characters. There are a few
recommended: but there is one constant character who I wouldn't think twice about locking in a trunk which I would then proceed to drop-kick down a flight of stairs into a vat of acid.\n\n2) Archetypal heroines. This one is less of an issue
voteText: however it really did feel like the author was just going through a checklist of sorts
helpfulPercent: particularly the side characters.\n\n3) Wasted plot potential/deus ex machina. This was present throughout a lot of the routes
votesHelpful: but none more so than the Mizuha route. Seriously
votesTotal: I finished that route and was extremely dissapointed. The book seems to hint and foreshadow at one hell of a plot
votesFunny: then ignores it and either timeskips or pulls some random BS that violates Knox's Decalougue seven ways from Sunday.\n\nAll of this said
column16: and find it well worth the price. I did splurge and pick up the voice pack
column17: and recommend such to all who would read this one. I also particularly enjoyed the soundtrack
column18: specifically the arrangements of "O Fortuna" really set the tone perfectly."

reviewText: G-senjou no Maou is by far one of the most interesting VNs I have ever played. It manages to have horrible morals, yet still portray an incredibly sweet love story. It manages to be disgusting yet endearing, deppresing yet hilarious. These charecters appear to be steriotypes, but the VNs twisted nature molds them into something unique. The art is qute good (While not amazing, the backgrounds can sometimes use work, and some charecters arent even drawn). The music is an excelent pairing of classical music with a modern vibe. The actual plot (While a bit reppetitive and drawn out at some points) extremely interesting, but the way it manages to suprise me is incredible. As for the endings (I have gotten Tsubikis good ending, Kanons good ending, and Usamis true ending) they always go through their ups and downs, always leaving me tense. I would highly reccomend this game, besides its various shortcomings and originally pornographic nature (Which hey, I personally find no error), this game is a masterpiece of a VN.\n\n8.7 out of 10, a must play.

reviewText:
G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String Review
Story

The Devil on G-String has an engaging story. It does take until the end of Chapter 1 to do so though. Also, the main story gets more and more intense per chapter too. The writing is excellent, but has some vulgarity and many pop culture references. In the end, the story made me feel all kinds of emotions.

Rating: 8.5/10

Graphics

All I can say is that the graphics look nice. The character art, backgrounds, and UI have nice synergy.

Rating: 9.5/10

Music and Sound

Most of the music was an interesting rendition of classical music. The music still managed to be creative enough in its own way though. I could feel the intensity and emotion of each song. The sound effects are pretty average, but get the job done just fine. Both the music and sound made reading the text more immersive.

Rating: 9/10

Characters

Each of the characters have a distinct personality and text color. They range from having a dark past to an innocent childhood. Throughout the story, you can see the characters developing themselves and their relationships. I felt empathy, sympathy, happiness, anger, sadness, etc. towards the characters. Not too many character tropes, like a tsundere, are used either.

Rating: 10/10

Gameplay and Miscellanous

The gameplay is very simple and works well. Saving and Loading works well (especially with 150 save slots plus the quick save file). I found no bugs in the game either.

Rating: 10/10

Overall Score:  47/50

reviewText:
One of the top 20 Visual Novels on VNDB
G-Senjou no Maou is currently one of the few good Visual Novels that made their way to Steam. An interesting story of cat & mouse backed up by a great soundtrack, it is among the rare games that make you play a villain... a see the consequences of your choices if you decide to remain so.

Have fun reading.

9/10, I had a great time.

reviewText:
TL:DR Solid story and art. Good game. But the romance is a bit cliche (not that you get to see any of it).

Tsubaki's and Shiratori's route weren't terrible but not great either. Still it helps set the ground work for the true route (usami). Kanon's route was pretty good too. They took some liberties with the story. Some of it is hard to believe. But overall it's an entraining ride.

As for the romance itself. Like I said it's pretty slim pickings. Especially since this is an all ages version. But then again I don't think romance was really the focus of this story.

There's quite a bit of what first appears to be fridge logic in Tsubaki's route. Some of which is explained after the fact or lampshaded but after a while I stopped caring as there are a lot of little twists throughout the story.

reviewText: This is honestly one of the greatest games that I've ever played. The story for this game was so captivating that I could hardly walk away from it for even a few minutes until a section of it was completed. I spent the vast majority of a week playing it seemingly nonstop all day and throughout the night, day after day unti it was done. My only regret is that it eventually came to an end. I strongly reccomend this game to anyone even remotely interested in this game, pay no mind to the title and play it for yourselves. I hope you all enjoy it as much as I have.

reviewText:
A great Visual Novel (VN) with a serious story (just expect a plot twist near the end) and an excellent soundtrack. Despite some of the other routes being somewhat weak, the main route is amazing and will leave you wanting for more. I've even read this VN several times with the unofficial version each year because of how good it is.

This version is better due to:
-Higher resolution and new aspect ratio (720p and 16:9)
-A nicer looking user interface
-Sprites look better


There is cut content (H-scenes) and some cropped CGs but it should not affect the story much. Unless you're a cheapskate, please buy the voice version to enjoy this VN fully.

reviewText:
A good, dark and twisted plot that takes some unexpected turns. The main character (you) is far from the usual 'knight in shining armour' or complete div that seems to be the norm in these VN's
A lot of thought and effort has been taken with the story with even some of the the minor characters getting fleshed out  in the differing paths.
A very Japanese (unsurprisingly) view of the west (almost the stereotypical standpoint) is shown in some paths, which i believe is a regular stance for the producer
Well worth the money if you are looking for VN that isnt all boobs and shagging or fluffy bunny girlies and/or you have a slightly darker view on the world
A class above most VN’s on steam at the minute
p.s. Although it may seem to be a marketing ploy the voice pack adds a great deal to overall ambiance of the title

reviewText: I really didn't know what to expect coming into this game, but I did thoroughly enjoy it! Yakuza and classical music, who woulda thought? Once you get back the bizarre remixes of classical music that mostly sound like Casio does the classics
date: you've got a complicated and interesting cast of characters, a well-maintained sense of atmosphere, and some really cool games of cat-and-mouse. The mystery is fairly easy, however, and both the culprit and final twist were easy to figure out almost immediately, even with the red herrings and faux-credits. Still a fun, thrilling VN!

I think having to pay extra for the voices is a little wonky though so I recommend buying an actual copy of the game; Same price, better quality.\n\nAkabeisoft2 is a great VN company, I recommend most of their works.

reviewText:
I have a lot of VNs yet to read, but this is easily my second favourite and my favourite that's on Steam. Very entertaining thriller with loads of twists, top notch classical soundtrack that's over 70 tracks long and filled with new takes on many legendary songs, and a final few chapters that are incredible.

Weak points include the voices (which are REALLY good) doubling the price of the game, a few writing missteps at some points, and not so great backgrounds art wise.

Overall, I feel it's somewhere between an 8.5 and a 9 out of 10, leaning towards 9. Hugely recommended.
